expanded_description: The substitution method is an algebraic technique for solving systems of equations. Unlike graphing, which can be imprecise, substitution gives exact solutions by replacing one variable with an equivalent expression. This method is particularly useful when one equation is already solved for a variable or can be easily manipulated to isolate one variable.

core_concept.principle: To solve a system by substitution: (1) Solve one equation for one variable in terms of the other. (2) Substitute this expression into the other equation. (3) Solve the resulting equation for the remaining variable. (4) Substitute back to find the value of the first variable. (5) Check the solution in both original equations.
core_concept.explanation: Think of substitution as solving a puzzle where one piece gives you information about another. If you know that $x = y + 3$, you can replace every $x$ in the other equation with $y + 3$. This turns a system of two equations into a single equation you can solve.

image.alt: Flowchart showing substitution process: isolate variable, substitute, solve, back-substitute
image.caption: Figure 7.3.1: The substitution method process.

sections.introduction: Substitution is most efficient when one equation is already solved for a variable or can be easily solved.

key_concept.definition:
Substitution is particularly useful when:
• One equation is already solved for $x$ or $y$ (e.g., $y = 2x + 3$)
• One variable has a coefficient of 1 or -1, making it easy to isolate
• The equations are in a form that makes isolation straightforward
key_concept.context: Recognizing when substitution is efficient saves time and reduces algebraic errors.

image.alt: Examples: y = 2x + 1, x = 3y - 2, 2x + y = 5 (y easy to isolate)
image.caption: Figure 7.3.3: Good candidates for substitution.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Good Candidates for Substitution

image.caption: Figure 7.3.4: Which systems are well-suited for substitution?

worked_examples.problem:
For each system, determine if substitution would be a good method. Explain why or why not.
a) $\begin{cases} y = 3x - 2 \\ 2x + 5y = 11 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 12 \\ 4x - 5y = 20 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} x = 4y + 1 \\ 3x - 2y = 10 \end{cases}$
d) $\begin{cases} 3x + 2y = 8 \\ 5x - 3y = 1 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.step: a) First equation solved for y

step_by_step.explanation: Could solve for a variable, but coefficients aren't 1
step_by_step.calculation: Possible but might be messy; elimination might be better

step_by_step.step: c) First equation solved for x

step_by_step.explanation: All coefficients are not 1, no variable easily isolated

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Yes, b) Possibly, c) Yes, d) Elimination preferred
worked_examples.concept_applied: Substitution is best when a variable is already isolated or easy to isolate.

image.alt: Summary of when to use substitution
image.caption: Figure 7.3.5: When to use substitution summary.

sections.section_title: 7.3.2 Basic Substitution: One Variable Already Isolated
sections.introduction: The simplest substitution problems are those where one equation is already solved for a variable.

introduction_image.alt: System with one equation solved for y
introduction_image.caption: Figure 7.3.6: Basic substitution example.

key_concept.definition: When an equation is in the form $y = mx + b$ or $x = c$, substitute that expression directly into the other equation. This creates a single equation in one variable that you can solve.
key_concept.context: This is the most straightforward application of substitution.

worked_examples.title: Substitution with Variable Already Isolated

image.caption: Figure 7.3.8: Solve each system by substitution.

worked_examples.problem:
Solve each system by substitution:
a) $\begin{cases} y = 2x + 1 \\ 3x + 2y = 11 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} x = 3y - 2 \\ 2x + 5y = 9 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} y = -x + 4 \\ 4x - 3y = 2 \end{cases}$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Substitute the isolated variable expression directly into the other equation.

process_flow.description: Look for an equation already solved for $x$ or $y$ (or easily solvable).
process_flow.mechanism: Forms like $y = mx + b$ or $x = c$ are ideal.

process_flow.description: Replace the variable in the other equation with the expression.
process_flow.mechanism: Use parentheses to avoid sign errors.

process_flow.description: Solve the resulting equation using standard techniques.
process_flow.mechanism: Simplify, combine like terms, isolate variable.

process_flow.description: Plug the found value back into the isolated equation to find the other variable.
process_flow.mechanism: Use the original expression from step 1.

process_flow.description: Verify that the ordered pair satisfies both original equations.

sections.introduction: Sometimes no variable is already isolated. In these cases, we choose one equation and solve for one variable before substituting.

key_concept.definition: When neither variable is isolated, choose an equation and a variable to solve for. Look for a variable with coefficient 1 or -1 to make isolation easiest. Then substitute that expression into the other equation.
key_concept.context: This adds one step to the process but follows the same principle.

worked_examples.title: Isolating Before Substituting

image.caption: Figure 7.3.17: Solve each by first isolating a variable.

worked_examples.problem:
Solve each system by first isolating a variable:
a) $\begin{cases} 2x + y = 5 \\ 3x - 2y = 4 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} x + 3y = 7 \\ 2x - y = 4 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} 3x + 2y = 12 \\ 4x - y = 5 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.step: a) Isolate y from first equation
b) Isolate x from first equation
c) Isolate y from second equation

worked_examples.concept_applied: When no variable is isolated, choose one to solve for first. Pick the one that's easiest.

sections.introduction: Sometimes solutions involve fractions. The process is the same, but careful arithmetic is needed.

key_concept.definition: When solutions are fractions, keep them in fraction form for accuracy. Decimal approximations can be used for interpretation, but exact fractions are preferred in mathematics.
key_concept.context: Fractional solutions are common and perfectly valid. Don't be afraid of them.

worked_examples.title: Systems with Fractional Solutions
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each system by substitution:
a) $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 8 \\ y = \frac{1}{2}x + 1 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} 3x - 2y = 7 \\ x = 2y - 3 \end{cases}$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Fractional coefficients are handled the same way; just do fraction arithmetic carefully.

sections.introduction: Always check your solution by substituting back into both original equations.

key_concept.definition: After finding a solution, substitute the ordered pair into both original equations. If both equations are true, the solution is correct. This catches arithmetic errors and ensures the solution satisfies the system.
key_concept.context: Checking is especially important when dealing with fractions or when the algebra was complex.

worked_examples.title: Verifying Solutions
worked_examples.problem:
Verify whether the given ordered pair is a solution to the system:
a) System: $\begin{cases} 2x + y = 5 \\ 3x - 2y = 4 \end{cases}$, candidate: $(2, 1)$
b) System: $\begin{cases} x + 3y = 7 \\ 2x - y = 4 \end{cases}$, candidate: $(\frac{19}{7}, \frac{10}{7})$

step_by_step.calculation: Second equation satisfied → solution is correct

worked_examples.concept_applied: Substitute the ordered pair into both original equations to verify.

sections.introduction: Substitution can also reveal when a system has no solution or infinitely many solutions.

key_concept.definition: When substituting, if the resulting equation simplifies to a false statement (like $3 = 5$), the system has no solution (inconsistent). If it simplifies to a true statement with no variables (like $3 = 3$), the system has infinitely many solutions (dependent).
key_concept.context: This is the algebraic equivalent of parallel lines (no solution) or coincident lines (infinite solutions).

image.alt: Examples leading to no solution and infinite solutions
image.caption: Figure 7.3.28: Special case outcomes.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Special Cases
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each system by substitution:
a) $\begin{cases} y = 2x + 3 \\ y = 2x - 1 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} 3x - 2y = 6 \\ 6x - 4y = 12 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.step: b) Solve second equation for y

worked_examples.final_answer: a) No solution, b) Infinitely many solutions
worked_examples.concept_applied: When variable cancels, check the resulting statement: false = no solution, true = infinite solutions.

image.alt: Summary of special cases in substitution
image.caption: Figure 7.3.30: Special cases summary.

sections.section_title: 7.3.7 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when using substitution. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

image.alt: Correct with parentheses vs incorrect without
image.caption: Figure 7.3.31: Error - missing parentheses.

classifications.value: Using the same equation for both steps.
characteristics: Isolating from equation A, then substituting back into equation A
Getting an identity instead of solving

image.caption: Figure 7.3.32: Error - substituting into wrong equation.

examples.process: Error: From $y = 2x + 1$, substituting into same equation
examples.explanation: Correct: Substitute into the OTHER equation

classifications.value: Using the wrong expression when finding the second variable.
characteristics: Using the original equation instead of the isolated expression
Arithmetic mistakes when substituting the found value

examples.process: Error: After finding $x$, plugging into original equation to find $y$ instead of using $y = 2x + 1$
examples.explanation: Both work if done correctly, but using the isolated expression is usually easier

worked_examples.title: Correcting Substitution Errors
worked_examples.problem: A student solved $\begin{cases} y = 2x + 1 \\ 3x + 2y = 11 \end{cases}$ and got $x = 2$, $y = 5$. Is this correct? If not, find the error.

step_by_step.explanation: Student likely made an algebra mistake in the substitution step

worked_examples.final_answer: Correct solution is $(\frac{9}{7}, \frac{25}{7})$. Student's arithmetic error led to $x=2$.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Always check solutions in both original equations to catch errors.

image.caption: Figure 7.3.35: Common errors summary.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to solve a variety of systems by substitution.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each system by substitution:
1) $\begin{cases} y = 3x - 2 \\ 2x + 3y = 13 \end{cases}$
2) $\begin{cases} x = 2y + 1 \\ 3x - 4y = 7 \end{cases}$
3) $\begin{cases} 2x + y = 8 \\ 3x - 2y = 5 \end{cases}$
4) $\begin{cases} 4x - 3y = 10 \\ y = 2x - 4 \end{cases}$
5) $\begin{cases} 3x + 2y = 12 \\ 5x - 3y = 1 \end{cases}$ (isolate first)
6) $\begin{cases} y = 2x + 5 \\ y = 2x - 3 \end{cases}$ (special case)

step_by_step.step: 5) Isolate y from first? Better isolate x?

summary: The substitution method solves systems of equations by replacing one variable with an equivalent expression. The process: (1) Solve one equation for one variable in terms of the other. (2) Substitute this expression into the other equation. (3) Solve the resulting single-variable equation. (4) Back-substitute to find the other variable. (5) Check the solution in both original equations. Substitution is most efficient when one equation is already solved for a variable or when a variable has a coefficient of 1 or -1, making isolation easy. When the variable cancels during substitution, examine the resulting statement: a false statement (like $3 = 5$) means no solution; a true statement with no variables (like $3 = 3$) means infinitely many solutions. Always use parentheses when substituting expressions to avoid sign errors. Fractional solutions are common and should be kept in exact form. Checking solutions is essential, especially when dealing with fractions or complex algebra. Substitution provides an exact algebraic alternative to graphing and is the foundation for more advanced solution methods.
